data.name: Canada Cup Trail
data.description: Canada Cup Trail is a a great trail usually ridden downhill. Although it can get a little technical, most riders will love its flow.

data.name: Canada Cup Trail
data.description: Canada Cup Trail is a great DH run that's a little technical but still very rideable.

data.name: Mount Work - Hartland
data.description: Network of mostly advanced mountain bike trails on the east side of Mount Work.
data.directions: Parking at the end of Hartland Avenue. Additional access at Meadowbrook Rd. and Robb Pl.

data.name: Gowlland Tod Provincial Park
data.description: Gowlland Tod Provincial Park is a 3,012.21-acre park on South Vancouver Island. This park protects an important part of the Gowlland Range which is one of the last remaining natural areas in Greater Victoria. Activities here include hiking, swimming, canoeing, kayaking, mountain biking and horseback riding.
data.directions:
The park is located on the east side of Saanich Inlet on Southern Vancouver Island. There are three park accesses: Tod Inlet, Mackenzie Bight and Caleb Pike.

The Tod Inlet access is located near Brentwood Bay, off Wallace Drive; Mackenzie Bight access is located off Rossdurrance Road, off Willis Point Road; the Caleb Pike access is on Caleb Pike Road, off Millstream Road near Langford. Gowlland Tod Park can also be accessed by boat via Tod Inlet.

data.name: Adventure Route Segment Of The Odt
data.description:
This is an outstanding 22 mile long forested singletrack trail connecting the west side of Port Angeles to Lake Crescent.  It is currently a segment of the larger 60 mile long Olympic Discovery Trail.  While not technically difficult it requires stamina to ride for extended distances on the trail.  The trail is quite scenic, with views into the Olympic Mountains, Mount Olympus, Lake Aldwell, Salt Creek and the Strait of Juan de Fuca.  It is a flow trail where grades average eight percent or less with quick downhill runs, switchbacks and excellent dry running surface.  You should be prepared with water, tools and pepper spray (in case of cougar encounters).

The map below only includes the trail up to its intersection with Joyce-Piedmont Road. From there, it is either possible to bomb the road down to Lake Crescent or continue the trail towards the Lyre River to reach Lake Crescent via singletrack.
data.directions: Drive to Port Angeles on US 101, drive through Port Angeles towards Forks and 4 miles west of Port Angeles turn right onto SR 112 towards Joyce. Once on SR 112 you drive 1.5 miles to trailhead beside SR 112 just west of the Elwha River Bridge crossing. Look for wooden entrance sign and kiosk with trail map on left side of the road. You can access the west end of the trail from the center of the Joyce Piedmont Road just south of the Joyce Crescent School or farther west at the Spruce Railroad Trail trailhead on Lake Crescent where you would ride back to the east across the Lyre River bridge and turn south up the Lyre River gravel road for 3 miles to intersect the west end of the singletrack trail.

data.name: Colville Mountain Bike Skills Park
data.description: Phase 1 opened August 10, 2019. Progressive trail riding area suitable for families and new riders, but also riders working on skills like drops and jumps.  Plans for phase 2 include DH and jump lines.

data.name: Burnt Bridge
data.description: A large and sometimes confusing network, Burnt Bridge features XC and DH trails catered towards more advanced riders with solid orienteering skills.
data.directions: From Duncan, BC, take Highway 1 southbound towards Mill Bay. When you reach Cobble Hill Road, exit the Trans-Canada Highway and turn right. In the town of Cobble Hill, the road will fork: Lake Shawnigan Road will go to the right and Cobble Hill Road will continue to the left. Take the right onto Lake Shawnigan Road. Eventually, once you actually reach Lake Shawnigan, you will take a right onto Renfrew Road. Stay on Renfrew Road past the lake, and when Logging Road forks off to the left, keep following Renfrew Road by taking the right fork. Take a right at the next intersection to cross the creek via the actual Burnt Bridge, and you will arrive at the base of the trails.
